Literature Review: Biofilms are complex, multicellular communities of microorganisms embedded in a self-produced extracellular polymeric substance (EPS) matrix. These communities exhibit unique properties that differ significantly from their planktonic counterparts, such as increased resistance to antibiotics and environmental stresses. Understanding the mechanisms of biofilm formation, maintenance, and dispersal is crucial for developing effective strategies to prevent and treat biofilm-related infections and fouling. Microfluidic technology has emerged as a powerful tool for studying biofilms due to its ability to precisely control the microenvironment, including fluid flow, shear stress, and nutrient gradients.
